fields.notes: # What is Free Software then? % cli $ "In the beginning ..." # Command line - our art started in the 60s

Very importantly we have to differentiate between the english version of the word "Free".

# Gratuit v. Libre - failing in the english language # beer v. folk

Libre

Gratuit

fields.notes:
The source was always available with the

Until this time customers did not pay for software or services separately from the very high price for leasing the hardware. Software was provided at no additional charge, generally in source code form;

This "unbundling" gives rise to a multibillion-dollar software and services industry.

fields.helper: "large volumes bug free code": GCC, emacs

fields.notes:
Freaky genius.

When he was 12, a Science summer-camp counselor who handed Stallman a print-out manual for the IBM 7094.

By the end of summer he was writing out paper programs according to the 7094's internal specifications never having seen a real machine.

years before getting access to his first computer. , Stallman spent the summer after high-school graduation writing his first program, a pre-processor for the 7094 written in the programming language PL/I.

See previous note 1: "As soon as I heard about computers, I wanted to see one and play with one."

---

Single mother, full scholarship to Harvard.

Graduated magna cum laude in Physics

fields.helper:
kernel source code available for academic purposes
.. but don't copy, change, derive, resell, etc ...
fields.notes:
%gates # M$ os code for academics >> if you *change* it and omgz if you change and and try to sell those changes - lawyer drop from the sky

Coincidentally these guys are direct contemporaries

They were at Harvard at the same time. But nearly certainly never met as Richards was doing Smart and Bill was doing Law.

Strictly, there is no definition.

# FLOSSD - Free Libre Open-Source (Software Development) (inherited from Tridg)

Some might say that it's the definition provided by the Open Source Initiative (OSI), but they were unfortunately unable to trademark the term.

Anyone who makes their source code available can officially say that their software is open source.

Let's take a step back.
fields.content:
Free
Libre
Open
Source
Software
Development

fields.notes:
This talk should always start with beer.

Really quickly want to clear up the terms
fields.content:
What is
"Open Source",
Anyway?

fields.notes:
"Free (to-use-change-and-redistribute) Software"

FOSS, FLOSS, FOSSD

Free Libre Open Source Development

When I say open source I mean "Free" as in free to skip and jump, free to learn from and redistribute as you will.

---

Some people really care about the difference between terms. It's not important here.

friː/
adjective

Able to act or be done as one wishes; not under the control of another.

Usually when I give this talk I go on about how software projects vary beyond description.

But actually Python projects are all pretty similar.

Don't be imaginative. Just don't bother.

- 1998 boardroom in Netscape, scared for free (anti-establishment), "implicitly threatening" agressive rebranding

An information source that's public and open. Eg, a Newspaper.

The term open source was appropriated in this way during the early tech-boom because business people could just not stand the idea of "Free" (even in the speech) sense is/was an anathema to them.
fields.content:
In a Netscape boardroom in 1998

(Eric Raymond was there)

63 Recognised Licenses

Apache License; BSD;
Eclipse Public License;
GPL and LGPL; MIT license;
Mozilla Public License 2.0;

A Copyright License is a
promise not to sue.

Rather than a permit to do something.

Can also set conditions.

Your own script?: Yes!

fields.helper: "all the fruits in the forest are poisonous"

(github) (all the fruits in the forest are poisonous) - 15% of all repositories had license files (Armin Ronacher) - 25% of those have the license only mentioned in the Readme file - if you're not sure, assume your work is derived and: - inherit license - don't use
fields.content:
15% of all repositories had license files
(ie: 85% are not FOSS)

If you're not sure:

Assume your work is Derived

Inherit the original license.
or
Don't copy the software.

- Eben Moglin: 9:1 hardware
- Bill Joy: embarrassed for us

- MPLv2 came out late 2012
- don't have to enforce, but have the option, hard to change license later

Every last major tech company is involved in the the OSI sense now.

fields.content:
Think like a Contributor

Change your brain:

learn to look for ways you can help.

Projects to work on will emerge naturally.

Serious/famous projects have:

serious,
dedicated,
committed,
professional

people working
on them.

fields.helper: Trustworthy committers are a very limited resource
fields.content:
"Ecosystem" around big projects

~ Work up ranks (hard work over long time).
~ Make plugins.
~ Be a good "Cultural fit".

fields.notes: Remember: You're contributing your time and energy
fields.content:
Rather than being a passive user

When you find bugs:
isolate, replicate and report themproperly.
Read and understand documentation
(for clarity and coherence).
Details, details, details (spelling, cruft).

Start Small

This is not the last time I'm going to say this.

Find out how to (who)
communicate

Find out how to
commit

Learn the "style" of the existing project.
(Phrasing, structure, etc)

If in doubt: copy
Don’t make up a new style: ask!

There will probably be rules.
Follow them (eg, PEP)

fields.helper:
First time: Like dinner parties and marathons
don't attempt something you've never done before.
fields.notes:
confident, easy: First time: Like dinner parties and marathons
don't attempt something you've never done before. You might waltz straight in. - it's like farting
fields.content:
For your first commit:
~ Punch your weight
~ Play to your strengths
~ Have Realistic Expectations

Students?
Bored with work?

Engage Socially

You are statistically more likely to stay involved with the project for longer.

fields.helper: A strong cultural feature of FOSS
fields.notes: With the occasional notable exception,
fields.content:
I'm awesome (✗)

You suck!

I'm not very good (✓)

You're awesome

fields.helper:
It causes unnecessary friction
and impedes your progress.
fields.content:
Drop your Ego

We all want the project to be the best.

fields.helper:
Giving good constructive criticism
is a really hard skill.
fields.content:
Learn to take "feedback"
(ie criticism)

Accepting criticism is actually a skill.
YOU ARE NOT YOUR CODE.

fields.helper:
A substantial number of us are
self-taught/from other fields.
fields.notes: (spend ... time ... studying these things
fields.content:
Most of our tools take YEARS to learn!

These are our basic skills,
we spend most of the time with them.
The all take practice.

fields.helper: Perhaps one your friends use (for easy support).
fields.content:
Text Editor

Pick a good one, learn to use it well.

Version Control (git, hg, svn, etc)

Learn basic commands solidly.
Get comfortable with major operations
(reverting, resolving conflicts, merging, branching, etc).

fields.helper:
You can make serious
contributions just using grep and find.
fields.notes:
CLI search tools

wildcarding, piping, command substitution, variables/control structures, iteration, etc
fields.content:
Command Line (CLI)

Learn to use it well (go beyond `cd`).

Regular Expressions (aka: regex).

Mailing Lists/IRC/IM

When/Which to use?
Who to ask about different matter.
General channels v. channels-with-a-purpose.
Language expectations.
Is there a code of conduct?

Accept Other People's Methods

Don't be douche about other people's
FOSS technical solutions that are currently working.

fields.helper:

I'm not talking to you. thxk.
fields.content: <h1>//PARTICIPATION<h1>

fields.notes: (and are usually very humble.)
fields.content:
On feeling stupid:
Everyone does.
Everyone is about most things.
The "best" leverage.

Rule of Thumb:
If you're stuck for 1⁄2 hour
go to: IRC, mailing lists, IM, etc

How long will you drive around before you ask for directions?

fields.helper: They know the feel because they've been there
fields.content:
Don’t agonise (spare yourself pain!)

Experienced people often can see/feel
you struggling (but will be polite).

In short term: it may be intimidating to ask
In medium term: you're learning faster

fields.helper:
No fluffy language, no big explanation.
Be cordial but just get to the core of it.
fields.content:
State it up front.
State as simply as possible.


təːs adjective
brief, short, to the point, concise, succinct

Decisions are made by the people who turn up.

User Groups, Hackerspaces, Conferences

IRC, Email Lists,

Congratulations!

You are already here. Thank you!
Share and enjoy.

fields.helper: It's all about how you handle it.
fields.content:
Communicate!
Communicate!
Communicate!

95% human problems are caused by ...

... and are solved by.

Tell people what you're doing.

For their sake.
Save them from wondering.

Start where you are,
Use what you've got,
Do what you can

All mistakes will eventually be washed clean by time and entropy


Communities are very robust.

~ Common in the community
~ Be respectful!

It's a small world after all!

fields.notes:
Probably the most valuable thing
I’ve learnt in the last 5 years.
fields.content:
Do what you say you're going to do.

But if you can’t: Communicate!
FOSS people are spectacularly understanding.

Issue tracker

Learn to write a good bug report.
"Design decision needed"/"close"v."feedback"
Fields should and shouldn’t use.

Learn to WRITE

(clearly)

Effectively communicate.

Popular markups (ReST, markdown, etc).
